title: Lucas Kook
text:
I am an assistant professor of statistics at the Vienna University of Economics and Business. Before, I worked as a postdoctoral researcher in statistics and causal inference at the Copenhagen Causality Lab. Together with Niklas Pfister and Jonas Peters, I work at the intersection of distributional regression and causal inference with a focus on biomedical applications.
I did my PhD at the University of Zurich under the supervision of Beate Sick and Torsten Hothorn. My PhD research focused on combining distributional regression models with deep learning approaches and causal inference to improve treatment decisions for acute ischemic stroke patients.















In March 2024, I started my new role as assistant professor of statistics at the Institute for Statistics and Mathematics of the Vienna University for Economics and Business.
New preprint ğŸ‰ â€œAlgorithm-agnostic significance testing in supervised learning with multimodal dataâ€ in collaboration with Anton Rask Lundborg. The corresponding comets R package is available on GitHub.
New preprint ğŸ‰ â€œModel-based causal feature selection for general response typesâ€ in collaboration with Sorawit Saengkyongam, Anton Rask Lundborg, Torsten Hothorn and Jonas Peters. Software implementing our method is available as an R package (tramicp on GitHub and on CRAN).
I acquired a postdoctoral mobility grant from the Swiss National Science Foundation for my proposal on Distributional Instrumental Variables Estimation (DIVE). During the fellowship, I will be working with Niklas Pfister and Jonas Peters at the University of Copenhagen, starting March 2023.
I successfully defended my PhD thesis titled â€œDeep Learning and Causal Inference with Transformation Modelsâ€ in February 2023.
New preprint ğŸ‰ â€œEstimating Conditional Distributions with Neural Networks using R package deeptrafoâ€ with software available on CRAN.

title: About me
text:
I am an assistant professor of statistics at the Vienna University of Economics and Business. Before, I worked as a postdoctoral researcher in statistics and causal inference at the Copenhagen Causality Lab. Together with Niklas Pfister and Jonas Peters, I work at the intersection of distributional regression and causal inference with a focus on biomedical applications.
I did my PhD at the University of Zurich under the supervision of Beate Sick and Torsten Hothorn. My PhD research focused on combining distributional regression models with deep learning approaches and causal inference to improve treatment decisions for acute ischemic stroke patients.
